documents.title: afternoon summary
text: mps from the commons public accounts committee have launched a withering attack on hm revenue and customs over its response to information it received about clients of hsbc 's swiss division dodging tax .
margaret hodge , the labour mp who chairs the committee , said accused lin homer , the hmrc chief executive , of a pathetic '' response .
hodge also said hmrc was sending out a really rotten message '' to people considering evading tax because its action was so weak .

she said hmrc was sending out the message that it 's a risk worth taking - the worst that can happen to you if hmrc can be bothered to catch up with you is that you may have to pay , you wo n't have a prosecution , you wo n't have any shame , you wo n't be an example to anybody else , you 'll get away with it '' .
she went on : that 's a terrible message to get out to british taxpayers , it 's a really rotten message .
lord fink , a tory donor and peer and party treasurer until 2013 , has accused ed miliband of slandering him in the commons .
fink denies being involved in tax avoidance .
( see 4.30pm . )

shabana mahmood , the shadow treasury minister , has called for a full and frank '' statement from lord green , the former hsbc boss and former tory trade minister , about what he knew about the tax scandal at hsbc .
in a commons debate on the scandal , she also said labour 's record on collecting tax was better than the government 's .

the financial times had a look at tax avoidance and the tax that has been collected by the government 's anti-avoidance measures against companies and compared that with the measures labour put in place for corporate tax avoidance during our term in office .
they found , actuall , tax collected by the government 's measures was going to be 90 % lower than those measures that were introduced by the labour party .

if i can quote directly , 'measures put in place by labour during its 13 years in power to counter corporate tax avoidance are projected to raise 10 times as much over the next four years as those introduced by the current coalition government ' .
david gauke , a conservative treasury minister , has defended lord green .
in the debate he said : lord green was appointed in january 2011 .
at that point the information about the fact there was an investigation into hsbc account holders was in the public domain , and so there was no big secret about this .

in terms of the conversations that were had specifically of course i was not privy to that , but there is no suggestion that lord green had acted improperly , was complicit in tax evasion or was involved in this particular activity and that could not be clearer there is no evidence that lord green was complicit in any wrong doing and that point remains the case .

opposition members can stand up and make allegations and suggestions but there is no evidence that he was engaged in that type of behaviour and certainly no information that was available to ministers to suggest that that was the case .
boris johnson , the conservative mayor of london , has said that hillary clinton , a frontrunner to succeed president obama in 2016 , wants britain to do more to fight islamic state .
after meeting her in new york , he said .
secretary clinton was very , very clear that she thinks there should be more engagement , more support from the west , from the uk , in backing the kurds , backing the peshmerga against isis .
boris johnson meeting hillary clinton at her office in new york .
rousseau/pa nick clegg has mocked labour 's pink women 's campaign bus .
he told the western morning news .
it 's just a tiny bit condescending [ to think ] because it 's bright and pink therefore women relate to it more .
it 's a bit like saying that political parties should drive around in macho red sports cars and blokes across the country will suddenly listen to them .
it is just a slightly patronising way to deal with voters it seems to me .
the pink campign pink van launched by deputy labour leader harriet harman in stevenage court/getty images that 's all from me for today .
thanks for the comments .
and lord paul , the former labour peer , has told itv news that he closed his swiss bank account four years ago .
libby wiener ( @ libbywieneritv ) lord paul - named by pm in relation to hsbc tax issues - tells itv news he closed his swiss account about four years ago # hsbcleaks
according to andy bell , labour is not going to back down over its lord fink allegations .
( see 4.30pm . )
andy bell ( @ andybell5news ) labour ; will be no backing down on lord fink , ed will make allegations again outside parliament # hsbc
kamal ahmed , the bbc 's business editor , has written a good blog on the public accounts committee 's hearing with lin homer .
he thinks there were three key revelations .
first , hmrc has now revealed it is looking to expand the scope of its investigation and is meeting other law enforcement agencies later this week .
sources tell me that hmrc is likely to meet both the serious fraud office and the police .
jennie grainger , hmrc 's director general of enforcement , told mps that they wanted to collaborate '' with other agencies .
if the sfo and the police launch separate investigations , that would be a serious escalation for hsbc .
the bank says that it has reformed the operations of its swiss private banking arm and standards of compliance are now much higher .
second , hmrc will also look at money laundering in connection with the hsbc data following discussions with the french authorities earlier this week .
third , hmrc initially believed that up to 150 of the people on the hsbc data list could face criminal prosecutions .
gauke says the government has been tough on avoidance and evasion .
its measures will raise £ 7.6bn in 2015-16 , he says .
labour 's measures will not raise anything like this , he says .
gauke says the labour motion ( see 9.13am ) suggests some measures for future action .
but there is no point proposing ideas that do not work .
for example , the government considered the idea of introducing deeming criteria to restrict false self-employment in the construction industry .
but this would require bricklayers to provide their own bricks , he says .
he says the government also looked at closing the quoted eurobonds exemption loophole , but decided this would not raise money .
gauke says the government has closed loophole after loophole '' in the tax system left by labour .
it has made more than 40 changes to the tax system , he says .
shabana mahmood intervenes again .
does gauke think lord green should make a statement about what he knew about hsbc ?
gauke says it is up to green to decide if he wants to make a statement .
back in the commons shabana mahmood has finished her openining .
i will post more excerpts from it later .
david gauke , the treasury minister , is responding now .
he says lord green was a very effective trade minister .
no regulator has suggested he was at fault in relation to hsbc 's swiss division .
at no point were ministers made aware of the evidence that has emerged in recent days of wrong-doing at hsbc itself .
shabana mahmood intervenes .
the media reports at the time made it clear that there were problems with hsbc , she says .
gauke says people could have accounts in switzerland without committing an offence .
it was known that a disk was acquired at the time with the names of people with hsbc accounts .
the investigation was into whether individuals had paid their tax .
the evidence we have seen recently , for example relating to bricks of cash being handed out , only came to the attention of ministers in the last few days .
david gauke parliament

documents.title: lin homer , hmrc boss , at the public accounts committee - summary
text: here are the main points from lin homer 's evidence to the commons public accounts committee hearing .
margaret hodge , the public accounts committee chair , accused lin homer , chief executive of hm revenue and customs , of not serving the british taxpayer '' .
during a hearing which saw hodge criticise homer severely and repeatedly , hodge accused hmrc of not doing enough to recover money lost through tax evasion and to prosecute offenders .
she said : it 's pretty outrageous what was going on .
it 's the first time in many of these leaks that there are really strong allegations not of egregious tax avoidance , but of tax evasion , and that is incredibly serious .

for you to sit there and say , as you are doing , that 'we could n't get the money in in the same way as the french and spanish did ' and 'we did n't litigate because we wanted to get the money in ' and yet you did worse on the money - it leaves me believing that you are not serving the british taxpayer .
homer told mps that 150 of the 3,600-odd people identified in the hsbc database were considered as serious candidates for prosecution .
but only one person has been prosecuted , she confirmed .
three cases were presented to the crown prosecution service , but two of those cases were dropped .
homer said that there were another 500 cases that were serious , but which were thought not likely to reach the test for criminal prosecution .
and there were another 400 to 500 cases where people were pursued for settlement .
around two thirds of the people identified had paid the right amount of tax , she said .
jennie grainger , hmrc 's director general for enforcement and compliance , told mps that it was hard to prosecute in these cases .
it is very difficult to prosecute from offshore .

one of the challenges - and particularly in a situation when you have stolen data , which is what this is - is that you have to be able to prove those facts another way in order for the cps to be able to take it forward .
homer said it took the cps 44 months on average to decide whether to prosecute a tax evasion case .

homer said hmrc had pressed the french authorities to permission to use the leaked data it supplied in 2010 to mount further prosecutions , but that the french had imposed strict conditions on what could be done with the information .
homer said that prosecution was only one part '' of what hmrc did .
prosecution is only one part of what we do .
it is a very important part of the toolkit but we are after tax and changes in behaviour and we are after a deterrent .
homer refused to say whether hsbc would be guilty of facilitating tax avoidance if it gave clients a credit card to enable them to withdraw funds from an undeclared account .
it would depend on the circumstances , she said .
homer rejected claims that hmrc had not done enough to get hold of the original data about hmrc customers leaked by herve falciani .
hodge said to her : one of my feelings of anger with you is that you sit there waiting for people to come .
you do n't go out and police in the way other authorities are doing and therefore they are getting more money in and more litigation .
homer replied : your assertions are not true .
we are very pro-active .
there is a suggestion that everybody else has been more pro-active .
there 's consideration of action against the bank in a small number of countries , there is no decision to proceed and there is no conviction .
there have been early moves to potentially charge one or two individuals .
homer said ministers would have been told when hmrc got hold of the leaked data about hsbc and suspect tax evasion by customers with accounts in its swiss bank in 2010 .
we are confident we will have told ministers that we were about to receive a big tranche of operational information .
she said the hsbc customers who settled with hmrc did so under the liechtenstein disclosure facility .
this meant they only had to pay penalties worth up to 30 % of their debt .
she said non-dom status was partly to blame for the fact that hmrc recovered less in tax from people with hsbc accounts in switzerland than the french and the spanish did .
she refused to say what dave hartnett , her predecessor , discussed with hsbc when he had a meeting at the bank in february 2010 .
she said it was unrealistic to expect hmrc to report general concerns about hsbc when it was asked for information before lord green 's peerage was approved .
hmrc was only expected to give information about green 's personal tax affairs , she said .

documents.title: lord fink , tory peer , accuses miliband of slandering him at pmqs
text: lord fink , the conservative peer , has written to ed miliband accusing miliband of slandering him in the house of commons .
at pmqs miliband said fink was engaged in tax avoidance activities '' .
fink says miliband should withdraw this , or repeat it outside the commons , where he would not be protected by parliamentary privilege and could be sued .

dear mr. miliband , today at prime minister 's questions , you alleged that i had undertaken 'tax avoidance activities ' in switzerland : 'let 's take stanley fink who gave £ 3 million to the conservative party .
he actually appointed him as treasurer of the tory party and gave him a peerage for good measure .
so now can he explain what steps he is going to take to find out about the tax avoidance activities of lord fink ? '
this allegation is untrue and defamatory .
these are the facts : i was posted by the man group to run their office in switzerland for four years from 1996 until 2000 .
during this time i had need of a local bank account to do simple things like receive my swiss franc salary and pay grocery bills .
as i already banked with hsbc in london , i set up an account with hsbc .
i subsequently set up an account with credit suisse as they had a branch much closer to my home and office .
i submitted tax returns in both switzerland and britain showing my revised tax status , which was accepted by the inland revenue .
i find it extraordinary that you have made claims against me that are without foundation or without contacting me .
i challenge you to repeat your allegation outside the house of commons - or to withdraw it publically .
yours sincerely , lord fink of northwood lord fink copus/evening standard/rex

homer says the fact that people hide money in swiss accounts is not new .
the leaked disc provided information about individuals .
it was widely known it was doing this .
this was a regular activity .
it is a big jump from that to assume a wider group of people were complicit .
if we discovered a major uk organisation doing something suspect , people would know when we charged them .
if we found evidence of that , we would charge them .
we talked to you about this data , she says .
and we told you , as a committee .
we say when we have information and are going after people .
homer says people knew hmrc had that data .
it was in financial times at the end of 2009 .
this was not secret . ''
a swiss bank had some clients who were not paying tax .
but of the 3,000-odd we looked at , two thirds turned out to be compliant .
q : what restrictions did the french impose when they gave you the information ?
and why did you accept them ?
homer says it is better to have some data than none at all .

hmrc was only meant to use them for tax collection .

homer says she does not know how many of those countries are using the information to follow money laundering .
the uk is now getting permission for this .

yes , says homer .

hodge says she dealt with appointments as a minister .
in that situation , you want as much information as possible , she says .
q : according to the guardian , dave hartnett , the former hmrc chief executive , had a lunch with hsbc in february 2011 .
asked what was discussed , he said people would have to ask hsbc .

homer says she can not say .

homer says they were asked about his own tax affairs .

homer says hmrc supplies information in relation to a number of procedures .
what hodge is asking is not realistic .
she is implying something wrong was going on at hsbc uk .

back in the committee , margaret hodge asks about a list of people with hsbc accounts in jersey .
grainger says hmrc is looking at 170 of these names .

documents.title: zac goldsmith 's statement on hsbc
text: turning away from the committee for a moment , zac goldsmith , the conservative mp , has put out a statement about the guardian story about his involvement with hsbc .
here it is .
it has never been a secret that i am a beneficiary of a trust set up by my late father and administered by a family office in geneva .
indeed this was widely discussed before the last election .
this report adds nothing to that old story .
to be clear , my very numerous family members around the world who are beneficiaries of the same trust do not own or control it , but like me , they receive income from it .
i have never had a swiss bank account , and do not control any swiss bank accounts .
i have never sought or been given tax minimisation advice by hsbc , directly or indirectly .
the media commentary around this is therefore wrong .
the fact is that i receive an income from an international trust , and i have paid taxes in full on all the income or capital gains i have received , irrespective of where these arise .
hmrc are aware of the structure set up by my father and has never requested any 'back taxes ' at all .
nor do they have any reason to .
on the issue of my contributions to the conservative party , they are a matter of public record and the vast majority are 'notional ' and relate to use of offices over the past ten years .

documents.title: labour labels cameron 'dodgy ' after he fails to answer question about tax talks with green
text: my colleague nicholas watt has filed a new story about labour attacking david cameron over his failure to reveal whether he discussed tax dodging at hsbc with lord green .
here 's how it starts .

labour has accused david cameron of acting as a dodgy prime minister '' after he failed on four occasions at pmqs to say whether he had discussed tax avoidance at hsbc with lord green before appointing him as a minister in 2011 .

as ed miliband claimed there was something rotten at the heart of the conservative government after the prime minister appointed green four months after the allegations about hsbc entered the public domain , downing street insisted that cameron had followed correct procedures .

downing street was forced to defend the prime minister 's role in appointing green in january 2011 after the prime minister sidestepped four questions - one from miliband and three from labour backbenchers - about whether he had spoken to the peer about tax avoidance at hsbc .
in his most detailed response - to the labour mp for washington and sunderland west sharon hodgson - the prime minister said : when i appointed stephen green every proper process was followed .

i consulted the cabinet secretary , i consulted the director for propriety and ethics and , of course , the house of lords appointments commission now looks at someone 's individual tax affairs before giving them a peerage .
i made the appointment , it was welcomed by labour and three years later they were still holding meetings with him . ''

labour accused the prime minister of acting in a ludicrous '' manner for failing to say whether he had personally held discussions with green about tax avoidance at hsbc and the government 's claim that ministers had no idea about the allegations at the time of his appointment .
i would use the word ludicrous , '' a labour spokesman said of the prime minister 's refusal to answer the question directly .

documents.title: mps question lin homer , hmrc chief executive , over hsbc

it has been alleged that the uk may have requested redactions to the senate report to conceal evidence of uk complicity in the mistreatment of detainees .
from the evidence we have seen and heard , we conclude that these allegations are unfounded .
the uk agencies did request redactions to the primary material which was used by the senate committee when drafting its full report .

they do not concern uk involvement or complicity in , or awareness of , the mistreatment of detainees .

we note that the uk agencies were at no stage provided with the draft reports .
rather they were given sight of heavily-edited extracts , which they could not retain .
we have seen the agencies ' internal file notes , but not the specific redactions proposed by the cia .

subsequently , the senate committee objected to some of the cia 's proposals , and there therefore needed to be further consultations between the cia and the uk agencies about the redactions previously discussed .

documents.title: pmqs - verdict
text: pmqs - verdict : often pmqs is hardest for an opposition leader when he or she is confronted with what westminster has declared an open goal '' .
expectations soar and , almost inevitably , they 're not met .
that 's what happened to ed miliband today .
he did not really lose and , if you had turned on the tv at 12pm with no knowledge at all about what might be coming up , you would have thought that he did rather well .
but , as i said earlier , in context it felt like a missed opportunity .
on the plus side for miliband , as a colleague has just pointed out in my office , his words read a lot better on paper ( or in pixel ) than they sounded in the chamber .
and , half an hour after pmqs , the labour charge against cameron - that he did not discuss tax dodging at hsbc with lord green when he should have done - looks more robust than it did at 12.12pm .
that 's because other labour mps asked cameron about this , meaning that his evasions started to look every more shifty .
and the prime minister 's spokesperson has n't helped .
that said , it still feels as if cameron has managed to sidestep a reputational clobbering .
why ?
partly because miliband chose to start by making this an issue about tory donors and cameron was able to respond with the point about labour having donors with hsbc accounts in switzerland too .

miliband said they had not been donors to the party while he was in charge , but the entire party donation system is so murky that it is hard to believe that any one party gains much from a row about it .
but cameron also benefited from being able to point to some significant steps that the government has taken to address the tax avoidance issue .
at the post-pmqs huddle journalists have been trying to get an answer from the prime minister 's spokesperson about whether david cameron discussed tax evasion at hsbc with lord green .
according to paul waugh , they have n't been making much progress .

no10 : '' he answered that '' .
lobby : no he did n't .
no10 : `` he was asked the q + he gave his answer ''

text: earlier this week labour wrote to george osborne , the chancellor , with some questions about the hsbc affair .
here are the three key questions labour posed .
in november 2012 a senior hmrc official told the times that the government had adopted a selective prosecution policy '' towards cases related to hsbc .
later that month hmrc told the public accounts committee that another dozen '' criminal prosecutions were to follow .
however , there have been none since .
it seems hmrc took a deliberate strategy to minimise rather than pursue prosecutions , which would explain why just £ 135m has been recouped .

can you explain why only a single prosecution has been made given the scale if the alleged wrongdoing and what role ministers played in deciding on a selective prosecution policy '' for those accused of tax evasion or avoidance ?
people would expect you to have at least been aware of a decision of this seriousness .
lord stephen green was chairman of hsbc 2006-2010 and was appointed a conservative peer in september 2010 and then as trade minister by david cameron in january 2011 .

given that , as the financial secretary said [ on monday ] , the government was made aware of allegations of wrongdoing against hsbc in may 2010 , eight months before mr green 's appointment to government , failure to ask probing questions would have to be seen as wilfully negligent .

as chairman of the bank , mr green would either have been aware of malpractice or , if not , surely questions would arise as to why not and his fitness for such a senior government post of trade minister .
can you provide details of the due diligence carried out by the government in advance of lord green 's appointment concerning allegations against hsbc and lord green 's role in relation to them ?
when the french authorities passed the hsbc caseload to hmrc in may 2010 we would expect the government to have taken swift action .
at what point were ministers made aware of its existence , when did you and the prime minister personally find out , and what action was then taken ?

edward troup , hmrc 's second permanent secretary , was due to appear alongside lin homer , hmrc 's chief executive , and jim harra , the director general of business tax , in front of the influential public accounts committee this afternoon .
the session is notionally about the work of hmrc .
but the trio were due to be grilled by the mps about why more action was not taken against a list of 6,000 former clients of hmrc 's swiss arm whose details were leaked to hmrc in 2010 .
however hmrc told the committee this morning at the 11th hour that he will not be attending .

margaret hodge mp , the committee 's chairman , is understood to be furious about the last minute withdrawal and has ordered him to appear on 4 march at a special hearing into hsbc and the controversy about historic tax avoidance at its swiss subsidiary .
and here 's some reaction to nicola sturgeon 's comments .
from margaret curran , the labour mp and shadow scottish secretary scotland ca n't afford another five years of david cameron , but nicola sturgeon wants to help the tories get back into power .
every vote for the snp in may is another boost for david cameron , and makes it more likely that he will be prime minister for another five years .
labour has a fair plan to balance the books but the snp have stood against labour 's progressive policies , such as the 50p tax for top earners .
from alistair carmichael , the lib dem scottish secretary all the bombast in the world will not change the reality that the uk government 's economic strategy is working .
whether nicola sturgeon likes it or not , this government has cut borrowing by £ 52n from the level we inherited .
that 's why the markets have regained confidence , the cost of borrowing and mortgages is at a record low , and we are vying with the united states for the strongest economic growth in the g7 .
we have achieved this despite the continued economic trouble affecting our immediate partners , especially our largest trading partner - the eurozone .
if the first minister has something serious to say on this subject matter , now is the time to say it .
by how much would she raise taxes , and by how much would she cut spending in the next parliament ?
or does she want to go back to the days of high borrowing , high mortgage costs , and an ever-bigger debt problem for the next generation to pay off ?

documents.title: sturgeon rejects austerity and calls for extra £ 180bn public spending
text: nicola sturgeon , scotland 's first minister , is delivering an anti-austerity speech in london this afternoon .
she previewed her argument on the today programme .
here are the key points .
sturgeon said that she wanted public spending increases in the next parliament , not cuts , and that her plans would free up £ 180bn for public services .

if over the life of the next parliament we were to allow modest , responsible increases in public spending , say 0.5 % in real terms , then debt and deficit would still be falling as a percentage of gdp over these years but we 're free up something in the region of £ 180bn over the uk to invest in infrastructure , innovation , growing the economy and public services .
she acknowledged that reducing the deficit was important , but she said other factors needed to be taken into account in fiscal policy too .
in terms of what i 'm setting out you 'd have debt and deficit reducing so i 'm not denying it 's important to get the deficit under control and start reducing debt .

what i 'm arguing is that to look at deficit in isolation is far too narrow because although that 's important , it 's also important to have stronger , sustainable , more solidly base economic growth .
she said austerity had failed .
i 'm going to make the argument that austerity has failed .
it 's failed on the terms the coalition government have set for it .
george osborne said in 2010 that next year he 'd have a £ 6bn surplus on his current spending - in actual fact he 's going to have a £ 49bn deficit .
austerity has failed and it 's time for a different approach .
i think it is important that we reduce the deficit and the debt and what i will set out is a different way of doing that .
she said she hoped snp demands would influence a future labour government .

i would certain hope , if there was a labour government dependent on snp support , which actually is the most popular preferred outcome of people in scotland , then we could persuade and influence a labour government to take a more moderate approach to deficit reduction .
she said the snp would not support labour if it backed austerity .
i am not going to support governments that plough ahead with austerity , that damage the poorest in society .
a labour government that looked to the snp for support would have to moderate its position in that regard .
that would be popular not just with snp supporters but i 'm sure with a lot of traditional labour supporters in scotland and across the rest of the uk as well .
she said many people in labour supported her approach .
i am sure there are many voices within the labour party who wish the labour party was arguing this more progressive , moderate , balanced , fair approach to reducing the deficit .
she appeared to rule out talks with labour about a possible deal before the election .
she was concentrating on getting as many snp mps elected as possible , she said .
asked her her relations with ed miliband , she said she did not know him well and had only met him a couple of times .
i 've taken the quotes from politicshome .
nicola sturgeon

documents.title: government amendment defending its record on tax avoidance
text: and here 's the government 's amendment to the labour motion on tax avoidance .
( see 9.13am . )

line 1 , leave out from 'house ' to end and add 'notes that while the release of information pertaining to malpractice between 2005 to 2007 by individual hsbc accountholders was public knowledge , at no point were ministers made aware of individual cases due to taxpayer confidentiality or made aware of leaked information suggesting wrongdoing by hsbc itself ; notes that this government has specifically taken action to get back money lost in swiss bank accounts ; welcomes the over £ 85 billion secured in compliance yield as a result of that action , including £ 850 million from high net worth individuals ; notes the previous administration 's record , where private equity managers could pay a lower tax rate than their cleaners , very wealthy homebuyers could avoid stamp duty and companies could shift their profits to tax havens ; further recognises that this government has closed tax loopholes left open by the previous administration in every year of this parliament , introduced the uk 's first general anti-abuse rule , removed the cash- flow advantage of holding onto the money whilst disputing tax due with hmrc , and allowed hmrc to monitor , fine and publicly name promoters of tax avoidance schemes ; notes this government 's leading international role in tackling base erosion and profit shifting ; welcomes the commitment to implement the g20-oecd agreed model for country-by-country reporting and rules for neutralising hybrid mismatch arrangements ; notes the role of the diverted profits tax in countering aggressive tax planning by large multinationals ; supports the government 's adoption of the early adopters initiative ; and recognises that as a result the uk is collecting more tax than ever before .
general election ( @ ukelections2015 ) # ukgeneralelection2015 85 days to go and here 's today election fact from the press association .
peers are barred from being prime minister .
the last to be prime minister was tory the marquis of salisbury who retired in 1902 .
conservative the earl of home had to renounce his peerage when he went into downing street in 1963 .
as sir alec douglas home , he secured a seat in the commons after winning a by-election at kinross and perthshire west .
on newsnight last night matthew hancock , the conservative minister , was asked to defend the government 's record dealing with the hsbc allegations .
it was not a particularly happy experience for him .

asked repeatedly by the presenter , evan davis , to explain what ministers knew about the allegations , which , as the guardian reports , where discussed openly in a commons select committee in 2011 in general terms , hancock said it was not appropriate '' for ministers to know about specific investigations by hmrc into individuals .
( but the complaint is not that ministers did not know about about an investigation into mr x , or whoever , but that the whole problem with hsbc 's swiss arm seems to have been ignored . )

hancock was on slightly stronger ground when asked if he understood why people were so angry about the fact that only one of the 1,100 people who have been investigated has been prosecuted ( a key fact in the labour motion - see 9.13am ) .

hancock replied : i , for instance , have been one of the leading people saying that those at the head of large banks that are systemically important should be liable for criminal prosecutions if they behave negatively .
because people need to know when people in positions of authority like that make a big mistake then they are held to account .
and so i completely understand the anger .
sometimes these prosecutions are very complicated .
i do n't know the details of it - it 's best that i do n't .
but , boy , do these people who make these decisions need to be held to account .
hancock was referring to the way that he personally pushed for penalties to be tightened for bankers who behave recklessly .

documents.title: labour 's motion condemning government 's record over hsbc and tax avoidance
text: here 's the labour motion on tax avoidance that mps will debate later .

that this house notes with concern that following the revelations of malpractice at hsbc bank , which were first given to the government in may 2010 , just one out of 1,100 people who have avoided or evaded tax have been prosecuted ; calls upon lord green and the prime minister to make a full statement about lord green 's role at hsbc and his appointment as a minister ; regrets the failure of the government 's deal on tax disclosure with switzerland , which has raised less than a third of the amount promised by ministers ; welcomes the proposals of charities and campaigning organisations for an anti-tax dodging bill ; and further calls on the government to clamp down on tax avoidance by introducing a penalty regime for the general anti-abuse rule , which is currently too weak to be effective , closing the quoted eurobonds exemption loophole , ensuring that hedge funds trading shares pay the same amount of tax as other investors , introducing deeming criteria to restrict false self-employment in the construction industry , and scrapping the shares for rights scheme , which the office for budget responsibility has warned could cost £ 1 billion in avoidance .
and this is what ed balls has said about the action labour would take on tax avoidance .
david cameron and george osborne have totally failed to tackle tax avoidance in the last five years .
they have failed to close the loopholes we have highlighted .
and the amount of uncollected tax has risen under this government .
i am determined that the next labour government will act where the tories have failed .
we will close loopholes that cost the exchequer billions of pounds a year , increase transparency and toughen up penalties .
and we will act in our first finance bill .

the revelations about how hsbc allowed its swiss banking arm to collude in multi-million pound tax dodging have been astounding - for example , they seem to be turning the scotsman 's peter jones into a revolutionary - and today they 're going to dominate proceedings in the house of commons .

they are almost certain to come up at pmqs ; then they will features in a public accounts committee hearing with officials from hm revenue and customs ; and finally they will be debated in the commons .
i will be focusing on all these developments .
as usual , i will try to keep an eye on the other stuff too .
